answers.body_markdown:
The problem is the SDK now logs a warning when it can't retrieve the [AWS instance metadata][1]. It may help to specify which AWS region you want using an [environment variable][2] (I haven't seen this work, but others have):

    export AWS_REGION=us-east-1

Alternately, the Spring Cloud team recommends suppressing the warning:

[https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-aws/issues/556][3]

[https://github.com/juho9000/spring-cloud-aws/commit/24edbdc57086f1043d3a49f6c8841cc1751ee747][4]
    

> On application startup, for its internal purposes Spring Cloud AWS performs a check if application runs in AWS cloud environment
by using `EC2MetadataUtils` class provided by AWS SDK. Starting from version 1.11.678, AWS SDK logs a warning message with exception when this check is made outside of AWS environment.
This warning message can be hidden by setting `ERROR` logging level on `com.amazonaws.util.EC2MetadataUtils` class.
>
> logging.level.com.amazonaws.util.EC2MetadataUtils=error




  [1]: https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/WindowsGuide/instancedata-data-retrieval.html
  [2]: https://githubmemory.com/repo/jnshubham/aws-glue-local-etl-docker/issues/3
  [3]: https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-aws/issues/556
  [4]: https://github.com/juho9000/spring-cloud-aws/commit/24edbdc57086f1043d3a49f6c8841cc1751ee747

answers.body:
The problem is the SDK now logs a warning when it can't retrieve the AWS instance metadata. It may help to specify which AWS region you want using an environment variable (I haven't seen this work, but others have):

export AWS_REGION=us-east-1

Alternately, the Spring Cloud team recommends suppressing the warning:

https://github.com/spring-cloud/spring-cloud-aws/issues/556

https://github.com/juho9000/spring-cloud-aws/commit/24edbdc57086f1043d3a49f6c8841cc1751ee747

On application startup, for its internal purposes Spring Cloud AWS performs a check if application runs in AWS cloud environment by using EC2MetadataUtils class provided by AWS SDK. Starting from version 1.11.678, AWS SDK logs a warning message with exception when this check is made outside of AWS environment. This warning message can be hidden by setting ERROR logging level on com.amazonaws.util.EC2MetadataUtils class.

logging.level.com.amazonaws.util.EC2MetadataUtils=error

items.title: Why does WebSphere search for a non existing EAR file and fails to publish an Application?
items.body:
I'm maintaining a legacy Enterprise Application which unfortunately runs on IBM WebSphere Application Server v. 7.0.0.45. The IDE is IBM RAD and the application consists of two projects: the first one is the web module and the second one the EAR container. The latter actually contains the deployment descriptor (application.xml), so no .EAR file is really generated on the file system within the EAR project.

The issue I'm having is that whenever I make any change in the web app and then save the source file, RAD first rebuilds the web app and then tries to re-publish the .EAR file to WAS, but the deployment always fails with the error: "Failed to open C:/Path_to_Application/xxx_w1_MyApplication/MyApplicationEAR/MyApplicationEAR.ear".

answers.title: Scanning the next line, but only to a certain length
answers.body:
You can do it using Reader#read method. Here is an example using BufferedReader.

import java.io.BufferedReader;
import java.io.IOException;
import java.io.InputStreamReader;

public class Main {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        // Create a buffered reader for System.in
        try (BufferedReader br = new BufferedReader(new InputStreamReader(System.in))) {
            char[] buffer = new char[99]; // Define the buffer of appropriate size
            System.out.print("Enter text: ");
            int n = br.read(buffer); // Read user input in the buffer,
                                    // n denotes number of characters read 
            String input = new String(buffer, 0, n); // Create string upto n character
            System.out.println(input);
        } catch (IOException e) {
            throw new RuntimeException(e);
        }
    }
}

The buffer would also contain the newline character if input is less than buffer size. You might want to strip it.

answers.title: Scanning the next line, but only to a certain length
answers.body:
"... I have an existing code, where I have to scan the next sentence that the user types into the console. This sentence can be no longer than 99 characters. ..."

This answer is similar to @RifatRubayatulIslam's answer.

Utilize the read method, providing a char array with a length of 99.
The new-line delimiter will be included here, you can use String#trim, or String#stripTrailing, to remove it.

try (Reader r = new InputStreamReader(System.in)) {
    char[] a = new char[99];
    int n = r.read(a);
    String s = new String(a, 0, n).stripTrailing();
}

items.body_markdown:
I have an existing code, where I have to scan the next sentence that the user types into the console. This sentence can be no longer than 99 characters. My current code takes the `.nextLine()` method, and saves whatever was typed, in a String. Than it checks the length of that String, if it's above 99, I use the `.substring(0,99)` method to cut off the excess. This works just fine, but I find it really ugly.

The problem is that if, let's say, a user would decide to copy-paste both volumes of Lev Tolstojs *War and Peace* into the console, my program would first try to save that as a String for no reason whatsoever, as I only need the first 99 characters. The question arises: Is there a way to tell the scanner to stop scanning after a certain number of characters? It would be cheaper, than scanning everything and than only using the part I need.
items.title: Scanning the next line, but only to a certain length
items.body:
I have an existing code, where I have to scan the next sentence that the user types into the console. This sentence can be no longer than 99 characters. My current code takes the .nextLine() method, and saves whatever was typed, in a String. Than it checks the length of that String, if it's above 99, I use the .substring(0,99) method to cut off the excess. This works just fine, but I find it really ugly.

The problem is that if, let's say, a user would decide to copy-paste both volumes of Lev Tolstojs War and Peace into the console, my program would first try to save that as a String for no reason whatsoever, as I only need the first 99 characters. The question arises: Is there a way to tell the scanner to stop scanning after a certain number of characters? It would be cheaper, than scanning everything and than only using the part I need.

answers.title: get path from an image on linux with Java
answers.body:
obtenerRutaContenido(File.separator + "html" + File.separator + "Correo.html"),
...
obtenerRutaContenido((File.separator  +"html" + File.separator + "PiePagina.html"));
...
obtenerImagen(("html" + File.separator + "Logo-AcertumBank-S.jpg"));

If obtenerRutaContenido() and obtenerImagen() are similar you would need to start path with File.separator too.

answers.title: get path from an image on linux with Java
answers.body:
Primarily you do not have a File (on the file system) but a resource (in a jar/war/class path/...).

public MimeBodyPart obtenerImagen(String urlImagen) throws IOException, MessagingException {
    logger.info("entro");
    URL url = getClass().getClassLoader().getResource(urlImagen);
    MimeBodyPart attachmentPart = new MimeBodyPart(url.openStream());
    attachmentPart.setFileName(url.getFile()); // Just "xyz.jpg" maybe
    attachmentPart.setDisposition(MimeBodyPart.INLINE);
    //attachmentPart.setContentType("image/jpeg");
    return attachmentPart;
}

This takes the InputStream of the resource to the MimeBodyPart constructor to fill the contents of it.

public MimeBodyPart obtenerImagen(String urlImagen) throws IOException, MessagingException{
    logger.info("entro");
    URL url = getClass().getClassLoader().getResource(urlImagen);
    logger.info("url" + url);
    MimeBodyPart attachmentPart = new MimeBodyPart();
    logger.info("url.getPath()" + url.getPath().toString());
    attachmentPart.attachFile(url.getPath());
    attachmentPart.setDisposition(MimeBodyPart.INLINE);
    return attachmentPart;
}

answers.body_markdown: You do not need to 'clean' every time you build. If I recall gradle should only rebuild files that you've modified and all their dependents. See https://stackoverflow.com/questions/29028748/why-run-gradle-clean for the second part of your question.
answers.title: Do we need to clean the project each time when I develop?
answers.body: You do not need to 'clean' every time you build. If I recall gradle should only rebuild files that you've modified and all their dependents. See Why run 'gradle clean'? for the second part of your question.

items.body_markdown:
I have a huge java web-project. Recently I have migrated to **gradle** build from ant build.

**Is it necessary to do 'clean' task each time I build ?**<br>
*Or*<br>
**What is the actual purpose of 'clean' task ?**

(*I know that 'clean' will clean the output directory. But I think always the files will get replaced each time I compile.* Then why do we need to spend time to clean again)

*There is one reason to clean* (as I know) :
If you remove a file and build without cleaning it, the old file will remain in the output folder until you clean it.
items.title: Do we need to clean the project each time when I develop?
items.body:
I have a huge java web-project. Recently I have migrated to gradle build from ant build.

Is it necessary to do 'clean' task each time I build ?
Or
What is the actual purpose of 'clean' task ?

(I know that 'clean' will clean the output directory. But I think always the files will get replaced each time I compile. Then why do we need to spend time to clean again)

There is one reason to clean (as I know) : If you remove a file and build without cleaning it, the old file will remain in the output folder until you clean it.

answers.title: Mapping specific subfields from JSON to Java Class properties on Android
answers.body:
One solution is to transform the JSON structure before converting to the POJO. You can try JSON library Josson which make use of Jackson instead of Gson.

public class Pais {
    private String nome;
    private String regiao;
    private int populacao;
    private String bandeira;
}

https://github.com/octomix/josson

ArrayList<Pais> paises = Josson.fromJsonString(textoJSON)
    .getJosson(
        "map(nome: name.common," +
        "    regiao: region," +
        "    populacao: population," +
        "    bandeira: flags.png)")
    .convertValue();
System.out.println(paises);

Output

[{nome=Christmas Island, regiao=Oceania, populacao=2072, bandeira=https://flagcdn.com/w320/cx.png}]

items.title: Mapping specific subfields from JSON to Java Class properties on Android
items.body:
I have a JSON like this:

[
  {
    "flags": {
      "png": "https://flagcdn.com/w320/cx.png",
      "svg": "https://flagcdn.com/cx.svg",
      "alt": ""
    },
    "name": {
      "common": "Christmas Island",
      "official": "Territory of Christmas Island",
      "nativeName": {
        "eng": {
          "official": "Territory of Christmas Island",
          "common": "Christmas Island"
        }
      }
    },
    "region": "Oceania",
    "population": 2072
  },

...
]

It is a list of countries I'm getting from here. I am mapping that JSON to a Java class as below:

public class Pais {

  @SerializedName("name")
  @Expose
  private String nome;

  @SerializedName("region")
  @Expose
  private String regiao;

  @SerializedName("population")
  @Expose
  private int populacao;

  @SerializedName("flags")
  @Expose
  private String bandeira;
}

And then I used GSON to serialize the whole thing with

    executor.execute(() -> {
      Conexao conexao = new Conexao();
      String URL = "https://restcountries.com/v2/all?fields=name,region,population,flag,numericCode";
      InputStream inputStream = conexao.obterRespostaHTTP(URL);
      Auxiliador auxiliador = new Auxiliador();
      String textoJSON = auxiliador.converter(inputStream);

      Gson gson = new Gson();

      if (textoJSON != null) {
        Type type = new TypeToken<ArrayList<Pais>>() {
        }.getType();
        paises = gson.fromJson(textoJSON, type);

        handler.post(() -> {
          paisAdapter = new PaisAdapter(this, paises);
          listView.setAdapter(paisAdapter);
        });
      }
    });

But the thing is, the fields 'name' and 'flags' will be parsed as objects, since they have other parameters inside of them, right? Is it possible to do something like mapping the "png" field inside the "flags" field from the JSON directly to my class parameter "bandeira," for example?

I've tried changing the @SerializedName notation to things like @SerializedName("flags.png"), but it didn't work. I imagine there is a specific way to do this.
